trans-unit.source: Tutorial - Get started with the Azure Batch .NET Library | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Tutorial - Get started with the Azure Batch .NET Library | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn basic concepts about Azure Batch and how to develop for the Batch service with a simple scenario
trans-unit.target: Learn basic concepts about Azure Batch and how to develop for the Batch service with a simple scenario

trans-unit.source: Get started with the Azure Batch Library for .NET
trans-unit.target: Get started with the Azure Batch Library for .NET

trans-unit.source: Start working with the Azure Batch .NET Library by creating a console application that sets up support files and a program that runs on several compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool.
trans-unit.target: Start working with the Azure Batch .NET Library by creating a console application that sets up support files and a program that runs on several compute nodes in an Azure Batch pool.

trans-unit.source: The tasks that are created in this tutorial evaluate text in files uploaded to Azure Storage and return the words that most commonly appear in those files.
trans-unit.target: The tasks that are created in this tutorial evaluate text in files uploaded to Azure Storage and return the words that most commonly appear in those files.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written in C# and use the [Azure Batch .NET Library](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt348682.aspx).
trans-unit.target: The samples are written in C# and use the [Azure Batch .NET Library](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/mt348682.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Prerequisites
trans-unit.target: Prerequisites

trans-unit.source: The accounts:
trans-unit.target: The accounts:

trans-unit.source: **Azure account** - You can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.
trans-unit.target: **Azure account** - You can create a free trial account in just a couple of minutes.

trans-unit.source: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).
trans-unit.target: For details, see [Azure Free Trial](http://azure.microsoft.com/pricing/free-trial/).

trans-unit.source: **Batch account** - See the **Batch Account** section of [Azure Batch technical overview](batch-technical-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: **Batch account** - See the **Batch Account** section of [Azure Batch technical overview](batch-technical-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: **Storage account** - See the **Create a storage account** section of [About Azure storage accounts](../storage-create-storage-account.md).
trans-unit.target: **Storage account** - See the **Create a storage account** section of [About Azure storage accounts](../storage-create-storage-account.md).

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you create a container in this account named **testcon1**.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you create a container in this account named **testcon1**.

trans-unit.source: A Visual Studio console application project:
trans-unit.target: A Visual Studio console application project:

trans-unit.source: Open Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, click **New**, and then click **Project**.
trans-unit.target: Open Visual Studio, on the **File** menu, click **New**, and then click **Project**.

trans-unit.source: From **Windows**, under **Visual C#**, click **Console Application**, name the project **GettingStarted**, name the solution **AzureBatch**, and then click **OK**.
trans-unit.target: From **Windows**, under **Visual C#**, click **Console Application**, name the project **GettingStarted**, name the solution **AzureBatch**, and then click **OK**.

trans-unit.source: The NuGet assemblies:
trans-unit.target: The NuGet assemblies:

trans-unit.source: After you create your project in Visual Studio, right-click the project in **Solution Explorer** and choose **Manage NuGet Packages**.
trans-unit.target: After you create your project in Visual Studio, right-click the project in **Solution Explorer** and choose **Manage NuGet Packages**.

trans-unit.source: Search online for **Azure.Batch** and then click **Install** to install the Microsoft Azure Batch package and dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Search online for **Azure.Batch** and then click **Install** to install the Microsoft Azure Batch package and dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Search online for **WindowsAzure.Storage** and then click **Install** to install the Azure Storage package and dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Search online for **WindowsAzure.Storage** and then click **Install** to install the Azure Storage package and dependencies.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.TIP] This tutorial makes use of some of the core Batch concepts discussed in [API basics for Azure Batch](batch-api-basics.md), highly recommended reading for those new to Batch.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.TIP] This tutorial makes use of some of the core Batch concepts discussed in [API basics for Azure Batch](batch-api-basics.md), highly recommended reading for those new to Batch.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Create and upload the support files
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Create and upload the support files

trans-unit.source: To support the application, a container is created in Azure Storage, the text files are created, and then the text files and support files are uploaded to the container.
trans-unit.target: To support the application, a container is created in Azure Storage, the text files are created, and then the text files and support files are uploaded to the container.

trans-unit.source: Set up the storage connection string
trans-unit.target: Set up the storage connection string

trans-unit.source: Open the App.config file for the GettingStarted project, and then add the *<appSettings>* element to *<configuration>*.
trans-unit.target: Open the App.config file for the GettingStarted project, and then add the *<appSettings>* element to *<configuration>*.

trans-unit.source: Replace these values:
trans-unit.target: Replace these values:

trans-unit.source: **[account-name]** - The name of the storage account that you previously created.
trans-unit.target: **[account-name]** - The name of the storage account that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: **[account-key]** - The primary key of the storage account.
trans-unit.target: **[account-key]** - The primary key of the storage account.

trans-unit.source: You can find the primary key on the Storage page in the Azure portal.
trans-unit.target: You can find the primary key on the Storage page in the Azure portal.

trans-unit.source: Save the App.config file.
trans-unit.target: Save the App.config file.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Azure Storage connection strings, see [Configure Azure Storage Connection Strings](../storage/storage-configure-connection-string.md).
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Azure Storage connection strings, see [Configure Azure Storage Connection Strings](../storage/storage-configure-connection-string.md).

trans-unit.source: Create the storage container
trans-unit.target: Create the storage container

trans-unit.source: Add these using directives to the top of Program.cs in the GettingStarted project:
trans-unit.target: Add these using directives to the top of Program.cs in the GettingStarted project:

trans-unit.source: Add *System.Configuration* to **References** in **Solution Explorer** for the GettingStarted project
trans-unit.target: Add *System.Configuration* to **References** in **Solution Explorer** for the GettingStarted project

trans-unit.source: Add this method to the Program class that gets the storage connection string, creates the container, and sets permissions:
trans-unit.target: Add this method to the Program class that gets the storage connection string, creates the container, and sets permissions:

trans-unit.source: Add this code to Main that calls the method that you just added:
trans-unit.target: Add this code to Main that calls the method that you just added:

trans-unit.source: Save the Program.cs file.
trans-unit.target: Save the Program.cs file.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] In a production environment, it is recommended that you use a [shared access signature](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee395415.aspx).
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] In a production environment, it is recommended that you use a [shared access signature](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/ee395415.aspx).

trans-unit.source: To learn more about Blob storage, see [How to use Blob storage from .NET](../storage/storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md)
trans-unit.target: To learn more about Blob storage, see [How to use Blob storage from .NET](../storage/storage-dotnet-how-to-use-blobs.md)

trans-unit.source: Create the processing program
trans-unit.target: Create the processing program

trans-unit.source: In **Solution Explorer**, create a new console application project named **ProcessTaskData**.
trans-unit.target: In **Solution Explorer**, create a new console application project named **ProcessTaskData**.

trans-unit.source: After you create the project in Visual Studio, right-click the project in **Solution Explorer** and choose **Manage NuGet Packages**.
trans-unit.target: After you create the project in Visual Studio, right-click the project in **Solution Explorer** and choose **Manage NuGet Packages**.

trans-unit.source: Search online for **WindowsAzure.Storage** and then click **Install** to install the Azure Storage package and dependencies.
trans-unit.target: Search online for **WindowsAzure.Storage** and then click **Install** to install the Azure Storage package and dependencies.

trans-unit.source: Add the following using directive to the top of Program.cs:
trans-unit.target: Add the following using directive to the top of Program.cs:

trans-unit.source: Add this code to Main that processes the text from the files:
trans-unit.target: Add this code to Main that processes the text from the files:

trans-unit.source: Save and build the ProcessTaskData project.
trans-unit.target: Save and build the ProcessTaskData project.

trans-unit.source: Create the data files
trans-unit.target: Create the data files

trans-unit.source: In the GettingStarted project, create a new text file named **taskdata1.txt**, copy the following text to it, and then save the file.
trans-unit.target: In the GettingStarted project, create a new text file named **taskdata1.txt**, copy the following text to it, and then save the file.

trans-unit.source: You can use Azure Virtual Machines to provision on-demand, scalable compute infrastructure when you need flexible resources for your business needs.
trans-unit.target: You can use Azure Virtual Machines to provision on-demand, scalable compute infrastructure when you need flexible resources for your business needs.

trans-unit.source: From the gallery, you can create virtual machines that run Windows, Linux, and enterprise applications such as SharePoint and SQL Server.
trans-unit.target: From the gallery, you can create virtual machines that run Windows, Linux, and enterprise applications such as SharePoint and SQL Server.

trans-unit.source: Or, you can capture and use your own images to create customized virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Or, you can capture and use your own images to create customized virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Create a new text file named **taskdata2.txt**, copy the following text to it, and then save the file.
trans-unit.target: Create a new text file named **taskdata2.txt**, copy the following text to it, and then save the file.

trans-unit.source: Quickly deploy and manage powerful applications and services with Azure Cloud Services.
trans-unit.target: Quickly deploy and manage powerful applications and services with Azure Cloud Services.

trans-unit.source: Simply upload your application and Azure handles the deployment details - from provisioning and load balancing to health monitoring for continuous availability.
trans-unit.target: Simply upload your application and Azure handles the deployment details - from provisioning and load balancing to health monitoring for continuous availability.

trans-unit.source: Your application is backed by an industry leading 99.95% monthly SLA.
trans-unit.target: Your application is backed by an industry leading 99.95% monthly SLA.

trans-unit.source: You just focus on the application and not the infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: You just focus on the application and not the infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: Create a new text file named **taskdata3.txt**, copy the following text to it, and then save the file.
trans-unit.target: Create a new text file named **taskdata3.txt**, copy the following text to it, and then save the file.

trans-unit.source: Azure Web Sites provide a scalable, reliable, and easy-to-use environment for hosting web applications.
trans-unit.target: Azure Web Sites provide a scalable, reliable, and easy-to-use environment for hosting web applications.

trans-unit.source: Select from a range of frameworks and templates to create a web site in seconds.
trans-unit.target: Select from a range of frameworks and templates to create a web site in seconds.

trans-unit.source: Use any tool or OS to develop your site with .NET, PHP, Node.js or Python.
trans-unit.target: Use any tool or OS to develop your site with .NET, PHP, Node.js or Python.

trans-unit.source: Choose from a variety of source control options including TFS, GitHub, and BitBucket to set up continuous integration and develop as a team.
trans-unit.target: Choose from a variety of source control options including TFS, GitHub, and BitBucket to set up continuous integration and develop as a team.

trans-unit.source: Expand your site functionality over time by leveraging additional Azure managed services like storage, CDN, and SQL Database.
trans-unit.target: Expand your site functionality over time by leveraging additional Azure managed services like storage, CDN, and SQL Database.

trans-unit.target: Upload the files to the Storage container

trans-unit.source: Step 2.
trans-unit.target: Step 2.

trans-unit.source: Add a pool to your Batch account
trans-unit.target: Add a pool to your Batch account

trans-unit.source: A pool of compute nodes is the first set of resources that you must create when you want to run tasks.
trans-unit.target: A pool of compute nodes is the first set of resources that you must create when you want to run tasks.

trans-unit.source: Add these using directives to the top of Program.cs in the GettingStarted project:
trans-unit.target: Add these using directives to the top of Program.cs in the GettingStarted project:

trans-unit.source: Add this code to Main that sets up the credentials for making calls to the Azure Batch service:
trans-unit.target: Add this code to Main that sets up the credentials for making calls to the Azure Batch service:

trans-unit.source: Replace these values:
trans-unit.target: Replace these values:

trans-unit.source: **[account-name]** with the name of the Batch account that you previously created.
trans-unit.target: **[account-name]** with the name of the Batch account that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: **[region]** with the region where your account is located.
trans-unit.target: **[region]** with the region where your account is located.

trans-unit.source: See [Azure Regions](http://azure.microsoft.com/regions/) to discover the available regions.
trans-unit.target: See [Azure Regions](http://azure.microsoft.com/regions/) to discover the available regions.

trans-unit.source: **[account-key]** with the primary key of the Batch account.
trans-unit.target: **[account-key]** with the primary key of the Batch account.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Add a job to the account
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Add a job to the account

trans-unit.source: Create a job that is used to manage tasks that run in the pool.
trans-unit.target: Create a job that is used to manage tasks that run in the pool.

trans-unit.source: All tasks must be associated with a job.
trans-unit.target: All tasks must be associated with a job.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Add tasks to the job
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Add tasks to the job

trans-unit.source: After the job is created, tasks can be added to it.
trans-unit.target: After the job is created, tasks can be added to it.

trans-unit.source: Each task runs on a compute node and processes a text file.
trans-unit.target: Each task runs on a compute node and processes a text file.

trans-unit.source: For this tutorial, you add three tasks to the job.
trans-unit.target: For this tutorial, you add three tasks to the job.

trans-unit.target: **[account-name]** needs to be replaced with the name of the storage account that you previously created.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Delete the resources
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Delete the resources

trans-unit.target: Because you are charged for resources in Azure, it's always a good idea to delete resources if you no longer need them.

trans-unit.source: Step 6: Run the application
trans-unit.target: Step 6: Run the application

trans-unit.source: Start the GettingStarted project, and you should see this in the console window after the container is created:
trans-unit.target: Start the GettingStarted project, and you should see this in the console window after the container is created:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and the files are created and uploaded, you should now see a new line in the window:
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and the files are created and uploaded, you should now see a new line in the window:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and the pool is created:
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and the pool is created:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and you should see this listing of the new pool:
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and you should see this listing of the new pool:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and the job is created:
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and the job is created:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and you should see this listing of the new job:
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and you should see this listing of the new job:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and the tasks are added to the job.
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and the tasks are added to the job.

trans-unit.source: When the tasks are added, they automatically run:
trans-unit.target: When the tasks are added, they automatically run:

trans-unit.source: Press Enter and you should see the list of tasks and their status:
trans-unit.target: Press Enter and you should see the list of tasks and their status:

trans-unit.source: At this point you can go into the Azure portal to look at the resources that were created.
trans-unit.target: At this point you can go into the Azure portal to look at the resources that were created.

trans-unit.source: To delete the resources, press Enter until the program finishes.
trans-unit.target: To delete the resources, press Enter until the program finishes.

trans-unit.source: Next steps
trans-unit.target: Next steps

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of running tasks, you can learn about how to automatically scale compute nodes when the demand for your application changes.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of running tasks, you can learn about how to automatically scale compute nodes when the demand for your application changes.

trans-unit.source: To do this, see [Automatically scale Compute Nodes in an Azure Batch Pool](batch-automatic-scaling.md)
trans-unit.target: To do this, see [Automatically scale Compute Nodes in an Azure Batch Pool](batch-automatic-scaling.md)

trans-unit.source: Some applications produce large amounts of data that can be difficult to process.
trans-unit.target: Some applications produce large amounts of data that can be difficult to process.

trans-unit.source: One way to solve this is through [efficient list querying](batch-efficient-list-queries.md).
trans-unit.target: One way to solve this is through [efficient list querying](batch-efficient-list-queries.md).
